divs: sighting detailsa single bright orange light that appeared significantly brighter than a star. approached from the sw and departed toward the north. appeared to go out of view like a satellite. too bright\to late at night to be a reflection off of a satellite due to sunlight reflection. looked like the object had a bright center with an orange plume that was pointing toward 2 o clock when approaching from sw. plume was oriented upward when directly overhead. size of elliptical like plume was larger that the bright center but no larger than the nail on my pinky finger. estimatation of the brightness would be initially equal or slightly brighter than the moon. initially looked too bright for a meteor, too slow for a large meteor\fireball. when it left toward the north, as bright as an aircraft with landing lights on. with the very light scattered fog, appeared to illuminate a small portion of the sky at moments. first impression was that it was an aircraft on fire as the brightness seemed to be varying while being continuously visible. second impression was that it was an upper stage performing an orbital trajectory change. video shows light going toward the north after i pulled off the road. color in the video appears to be off.
Summary: Satellite/meteor with a bright orange light and slight direction change.
